dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the fans rushing to the few platform ticket machin endless pennies being dropped and tickets torn out in the get onto the platform to see the boys. NORM has been waiting for the boys and he hurries them to their baggage, instruments and the drums are waiting, pil put into the guards' van. The boys turn and see the oncom girls pushing through the barriers and descending on them and shouts. They grab their instruments, RINGO makes for NORM plugs into a handy transformer and using their instr gun volley to stop the onrush of females, the boys blast number and start to sing. This stops the girls in their t settle down on whatever they can to listen to them playin As the boys are playing, we CUT BACK into the crowds. In see PAUL struggling and pulling to fight his way through join the other boys. He is dragging a very reluctant old him. The old man seems most disgruntled and we can see by how unwilling he is to be pulled and pushed forward throu girls. At last PAUL reaches the other boys. He sits the old man of cases and joins in the number to the squeals of deligh fans. The old man sits aloof and proud ignoring the whole JOHN, GEORGE and RINGO look enquiringly at PAUL who gives noncommittal shrug of the shoulders as if to say, "it's n and the number proceeds. SHOT of sudden horror on JOHN's face. PAUL follows his ey see the old man has doffed his cap and is busily collecti a disconcerted crowd. PAUL dives hastily into the crowd, suitable apologies extracts the old man and with a long s drags him back to the group. GEORGE and PAUL hold him fir finish the number, the old man standing there between the  the As the number finishes and the girls scream and shout wit guard blows his whistle. NORM and SHAKE grab the instrume drums, and with the rest piles the lot into the guardsâ€™ v head into their reserved compartment pursued by the fans moves off. They have successfully repelled all extra boar THE BOYS stand and wave to the fans until out of sight li girls running along to the end of the platform waving and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys relax, sitting down on one side of the compartme about to settle down and make themselves at home when fir nudges GEORGE who in turn nudges JOHN. Opposite them is s LITTLE OLD MAN. He is holding himself stiff, erect and ve The three boys look at him enquiringly but with an elabor looks away from them and out of the window. PAUL catches his eye and winks at the LITTLE OLD MAN. He PAUL, scowls at the other three then looks firmly out of again. The boys turn on PAUL crowding around him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Eh ... pardon me for asking but who's that little old man?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What little old man?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (pointing) That little old man.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, that one. That's me Grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's not your Grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It is, y'know.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But your Grandfather lives in your house. I've seen him.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, that's me other Grandfather, but this one's me Grandfather and all.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How d'you reckon that one out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... everyone's entitled to two, aren't they, and this is me other one.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (long suffering) Well we know that but what's he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, me mother thought the trip 'ud do him good.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh ... he's nursing a broken heart. The lads all look intently at the GRANDFATHER.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Aah ... the poor old thing. He leans across to GRANDFATHER.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Eh, Mister... are you nursing a broken heart then? The GRANDFATHER nods soulfully glares at him, in a way th yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (whispering) You see, he was going to get married but she threw him over for a butcher.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: A butcher?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, she was fickle.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Aye and fond of fresh meat and all.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (seriously) No ... it was his sweetbreads. She was dead kinky for sweetbreads. Anyroad, me mother thought it'ud give him a change of scenery, like.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. indicates  He inspects GRANDFATHER carefully.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to PAUL) Eh, he's a nice old man, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, he's very clean, y'know. They all agree with PAUL. JOHN has been examining GRANDFATHER. He now leans forward

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (in an over-friendly voice) Hello, Grandfather!

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (delightedly) He can talk then?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (indignantly) Course he can talk. He's a human being, like. Isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (grinning) Well ... if he's your Grandfather, who knows? The lads all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: And we're looking after him, are we?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I'll look after meself.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aye, that's what I'm afraid of!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He's got you worried, then?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Him, he costs you a fortune in breach of promise cases. He's a villain and a right mixer as well.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (disbelieving) Gerron.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, straight up.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: The lad's given you the simple truth. I'm cursed wid irresistible charm, I'm too attractive to be let loose. At this moment, SHAKE, a tall man who works with the BOYS the door of the compartment.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: You got on all right then?

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Hi, Shake.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: We're here. Norm'll be along in a mo' with the tickets. He sees GRANDFATHER.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Morning! (whispers) Who's that little old man?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's Paul's grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Oh aye, but I thought ...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (cutting in) No, that's his other one.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: That's all right then.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (displaying Grandfather) Clean though, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Oh yes, he's clean all right. NORM the road manager appears behind SHAKE.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Morning, lads.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Morning ... Hi, Norm.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (checking them quickly) pulls open  Well, thank God you're all got here. Now, listen, I've had this marvellous idea ... now just for a change, let's all behave like ordinary responsible citizens. Let's not cause any trouble, pull any strokes or do anything I'm going to be sorry for, especially tomorrow at the television theatre, because ... He looks sharply at JOHN who is polishing his nails.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Are you listening to me, Lennon?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (off-hand) You're a swine, isn't he George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (disinterested) Yeah ... a swine.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (just as indifferent) Thanks... He sees the GRANDFATHER.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Eh ...

dialogues.speaker: BOYS IN CHORUS
dialogues.text: ... Who's that little old man?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Well, who is he?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: He belongs to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (accepting the situation) Ah well, there you go. Look, I'm going down the diner for a cup of coffee, are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We'll follow you down. GRANDFATHER rises.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I want me coffee.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: He can come with Shake and me if you like.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, look after him. I don't want to find you've lost him.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Don't be cheeky, I'll bind him to me with promises. Come on, Grandad. GRANDFATHER joins SHAKE and NORM.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (over Grandfather's head) He's very clean, isn't he? SHAKE and NORM collect GRANDFATHER and are in the process the compartment when a fat upper class city Englishman, J attempts to enter. There is a bit of confusion and they g with each other.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Make up your minds, will you! At last SHAKE, NORM and GRANDFATHER sort themselves out a enters with his case. The other three go to coffee. JOHNSON puts his case up on the luggage rack, then sits d movements are disgruntled ... he finally picks up his cop Financial Times and burying himself behind it, starts to moment he looks up, notices the compartment window is ope and without so much as a "by your leave" he closes it, gl BOYS and sits down again. The boys exchange looks as if to say ... â€œHello, Saucy!!"

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (politely) Do you mind if we have it opened?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (briefly) Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah, but there are four of us, like, and we'd like it open, if it's all the same to you, that is.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (rudely) Well, it isn't. I travel on this train regularly twice a week, so I suppose I've some rights.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Aye, well, so have we. He disappears behind his paper before the BOYS can say an RINGO pulls a face at the raised paper and switches on h radio. A pop number is playing. JOHNSON puts down his paper firmly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: And we'll have that thing off as well, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: But I... JOHNSON leans over and switches it off.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: An elementary knowledge of the Railway Acts would tell you I'm perfectly within my rights. He smiles frostily.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we want to hear it and there's more of us than you. We're a community, like, a majority vote. Up the workers and all that stuff!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Then I suggest you take that damned thing into the corridor or some other part of the train where you obviously belong.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (leaning forward to him) Gie's a kiss!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Shurrup! Look, Mister, we've paid for our seats too, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I travel on this train regularly, twice a week.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Knock it off, Paul, y' can't win with his sort. After all, it's his train, isn't it, Mister?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: And don't you take that tone with me, young man!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (accusingly) I fought the war for your sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you're sorry you won!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I'll call the guard!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aye ... but what? They don't take kindly to insults you know. Ah, come on, you lot. Let's get a cup of coffee and leave Toby the manger. The boys troop out of the door into the corridor. JOHNSON triumphantly. He is about to settle down to his paper whe tap on the corridor window. He looks up and we see presse window a collection of hideous Beatle faces.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Eh, Mister ... can we have our ball back! The man jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR OF THE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: The boys run away like a pack of school boys and disappea corner.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR OF THE TRAIN CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: From the P.O.V. of the door leading to the restaurant car The boys come down the corridor in full flight, laughing happy idiots. GEORGE and PAUL pull open the sliding doors look inside.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR RESTAURANT CAR
dialogues.text: From their P.0.V. we see the car is half empty and at a t centre SHAKE and NORM and GRANDFATHER are sitting. On the pile of photos of the boys. NORM and SHAKE are arguing. N very aggressive, much to SHAKE's discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Yeah, you want to watch it.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: (unhappily) It's not my fault.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Well, you stick to that story, son.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: I can't help it, I'm just taller than you.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (To NORM slyly) They always say that.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I got me eye on you.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Norm, but I can't help being taller than you.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Well, you don't have to rub me nose in it. I've a good mind to ... (he is about to thump SHAKE.)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (enjoying himself) If you're going to have a barney I'll hold your coats.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: He started it.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: No, I didn't you did...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: The old fella wanted these pictures and Norm said he couldn't have â€˜em, all I said was â€˜aw go on, be big about it.'

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Your Grandfather pointed out Shake was always being taller than me just to spite me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I knew it, he started it, I should have known.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Y'what?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You two have never had a quarrel in your life and in two minutes flat he's got you at it. He's a king mixer. Adam and Eve, meet the serpent. Anthony and Cleopatra, there's your asp. Divide and Conquer, that's this one's motto. He hates group unity so he gets everyone at it. The BOYS, i.e., JOHN, GEORGE and RINGO, look at each othe  PAUL.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aye and we'll have to watch it and all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I suggest you just give him the photos and have done with it.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: You're right. Here you are, old devil. SHAKE and NORM leave. GRANDFATHER grins triumphantly and them, then with a sweet smile he turns to PAUL.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Would you ever sign this one for us, Pauly? PAUL does so automatically but in the middle of signing h suspicious. GRANDFATHER smiles at him charmingly so PAUL signing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Come on let's get this coffee.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Before you go, I think it's only fair to warn you about me Grandson ... don't let our Paul have his own way all the time, 'cos if you do he won't respect you! JOHN, RINGO and GEORGE take this up straight away. They a be girls, RINGO jumps into PAUL's arms.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (coyly) Oh, Paul, you can't have your own way!!!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (invitingly, in a Marlene Dietrich voice) If I let you have your own way, you little rascal, will you respect me?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (choked) I'll murder you, Grandfather! JOHN waltzes PAUL down to an empty table and the lads sit

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Eh, look at that talent. They all gaze across the aisle. From their P.O.V. we see attractive young girls, RITA and JEAN, having coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give 'em a pull.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Shall I?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Aye, but don't rush. None of your five bar gate jumps and over sort of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now what's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (grinning) I don't really know, but it sounded distinguished, like, didn't it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: George Harrison, The Scouse of Distinction. We follow PAUL as he crosses over to the two girls. He pl on his head.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (in posh accent) Excuse me, but these young men I'm sitting with wondered if two of us could join you; I'd ask you meself only I'm shy. The two girls giggle together. JOHN and GEORGE are about to move over when GRANDFATHER s appears by their sides.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (sternly) I'm sorry, miss, but you mustn't fraternise with my prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Prisoners!!

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Convicts in transit to Wormwood Scrubs. Typical old lags, the lot of â€˜em.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS
dialogues.text: Y'what!!!

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Quiet, you lot, or I'll give you a touch of me truncheon. (He points at Ringo) That little one's the worst. If we don't keep him on tablets he has fits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting) Now look here!! GRANDFATHER grabs two lumps of sugar from the table and f into RINGO'S mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Get out while you can, ladies, his time's coming round for one of his turns. The frightened girls scurry out of the restaurant car. Th in amazement and horror at GRANDFATHER. They are completely flabbergasted. GRANDFATHER smiles at them benignly.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR OF RAILWAY COMPARTMENT
dialogues.text: SHAKE and NORM are seated. SHAKE is buried in a science f NORM looks at his watch, slightly worried.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: He's been gone a long time.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Who?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Paul's grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Oh, I didn't notice, where'd he go?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Down the ... er ...

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Oh, down the ... er ...?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Yeah, down the ... er ...

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Well, give a couple of minutes ... He resumes reading. But NORM goes on worrying.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR OF ANOTHER RAILWAY COMPARTMENT
dialogues.text: Grandfather is in full flight of conversation with a char lady, AUDREY, who is listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (proudly) Yes, I'm their manager, I discovered them.

dialogues.speaker: LADY AUDREY
dialogues.text: Did you indeed, Mr. McCartney?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Now, Audrey, I told you, the name's John. We show biz people are a friendly lot.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Of course, John.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Yes, they were playing the queues outside the picture palaces of Liverpool. Scruffy young lads, lacking even the price of a jam roll. Orphans, every Paddy's son of â€˜em. I saw their potential at once although I had me doubts about the little fella, a savage primitive, that Ringo, but it was him what gave in first. He picked up a brick and heaved it at me and I quelled him wid one fierce flash of me eyes. "Mister, can you spare us a copper?" he said. I was disarmed by the grubby little outstretched mauler ... So, I took them under me managerial banner.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: The usual ten per cent?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Oh, not at all, I let them have twenty-five; sure aren't there four of them?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (her eyes lighting up) How fascinating. Do go on ... (pause) .+. John.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: -+. Oh, I'm all heart, Ma'am, all heart ... Well, I let...

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR CORRIDOR OF TRAIN
dialogues.text: NORM and SHAKE meet with the BOYS as they are returning f

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Eh, have you got Paul's grandfather?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Of course, he's concealed about me person.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: No ... he's must have slipped off somewhere.  11.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (accusingly) Have you lost him?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Don't exaggerate.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You've lost him.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Put it this way, he's mislaid him.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You can't trust you with anything, Norm, if you've lost him, I'll cripple you.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: He can't be far.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I hope he fell off.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (mildly) Don't be callous.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: He doesn't like me, honest, I can tell ... It's â€˜cos I'm little.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You've got an inferiority complex, you have.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, that's why I took up the drums. It's me active compensatory factor. JOHN and PAUL run down the corridor. SHAKE and NORM turn and go in the opposite direction, GEORGE and RINGO follow other two boys.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR CORRIDOR OF TRAIN
dialogues.text: PAUL and JOHN look into various compartments. CLOSE SHOT looking into compartments in the manner of Groucho Marx. compartments we see from RINGO'S P.O.V. the occupant, a g woman, TANIA, with a small lap dog. She is beautifully and most expensively dressed. She look RINGO. RINGO smiles at her and she smiles back. She then beckons her. He looks around to see if she means someone else. She nod RINGO looks back enquiringly then points at himself as i â€œWho, me?" TANIA smiles enthusiastically. GEORGE has been watching all this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you going in?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: No, she'll only reject me in the end and I'll be frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You never know, you might be lucky this time.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: No, I know the psychological pattern and it plays hell with me drum skins. He blows the glamorous lady a kiss, then moves sadly on.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR FURTHER DOWN THE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: PAUL enters a compartment followed by JOHN. The TWO GIRLS JEAN, from the restaurant car are sitting there.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Excuse me but have you seen that little old man we were with? The girls jump up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We've broken out, oh, the blessed freedom of it all! (he extends his hands as if handcuffed) Eh, have you got a nail file, these handcuffs are killing me. I was framed. I was innocent.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Will you stop it! Sorry to disturb you, miss... He starts to drag JOHN after him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I was innocent. I was framed. I won't go back. JOHN is now by the door; he leers at the girls horribly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I bet you can guess what I was in for. He cackles like a maniac before disappearing, the door cl  13. him. A waiter carrying a tray with champagne and glasses on it one of the compartments with the blinds down.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How about that one? He moves towards the compartment.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (to Ringo and George) Did you look in here?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. I mean, it's probably a honeymoon couple or a company director or something.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, let's broaden our outlook. PAUL opens the door of the compartment.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR OF COMPARTMENT
dialogues.text: From the BOYS' P.O.V. we see GRANDFATHER and the elderly sipping champagne and nibbling caviar on toast.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (looking up) Congratulate me, boys, I'm engaged. PAUL enters and crosses over to him.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh no, you're not. You've gone too far this time ... and who's paying for all this?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: It's all taken care of. It's down on our bill.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, well that's all right. (realising) What?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Young man, kindly moderate your tone when you address my fiance.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Missus, but the betrothal's off. (He grabs GRANDFATHER by the arm.) I'll refuse me consent, he's over-age! AUDREY grabs GRANDFATHER's other arm and pulls back.  14.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Leave him alone, after all he's done for you is this the way you repay him? A tug of war now starts between PAUL and AUDREY.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (pulling) Him? he's never done anything for anybody in his life.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (pulling) You dare to say that when even those ridiculous clothes you are wearing were bought when you forced him to sell out his gilt edged Indomitables!! JOHN and GEORGE jump on the seat egging PAUL and AUDREY o

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Come on, Auntie, you're winning.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Get in there, Paul, she's weakening. RINGO attempts to interfere.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Look, Missus, this is all a misunderstanding, you see, he's ...

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Keep away from me, you depraved lout, I know all about your terrible past.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Y'what? She hits RINGO with her handbag and continues struggling GRANDFATHER. RINGO grabs her handbag to stop her hitting

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: He's given me a bad character, blackguarding me name to all and sundry. He's got to be stopped. It's not fair. RINGO pushes out into the corridor, forgetting that he is woman's handbag. A voice shouts off from outside.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OFF
dialogues.text: That's one of them ... stop thief!

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: From Ringo's P.O.V. we see down to the right the city ma approaching with a GUARD. RINGO turns the other way to th he is joined by [the] three other boys. From their P.O.V. do corridor we see the two girls, autograph books in hand, f ten girls from the same school. Both groups are closing in on the BOYS. There's no escape

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (looking down at the handbag in his hand) Oh Mother! !

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR LUGGAGE VAN
dialogues.text: Very dark, and behind bars we see GRANDFATHER. He is sitt up on a wooden box tea chest and looks pretty miserable. towards the CAMERA; in the foreground of the SHOT we see standing. In the background an impassive GUARD is reading a paper w throughout the scene.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (bitterly) And to think me own grandson would have let them put me behind bars!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don't dramatise. The CAMERA PULLS BACK and we see GRANDFATHER in the lugga compartment of the guards' van. In with him are a crate of chickens a chickens peck at him; GRANDFATHER moves listlessly away.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Let's face it, you're lucky to be here. If they'd have had their way you'd have been dropped off at Stafford already. GRANDFATHER proudly turns away from PAUL who dodges round still see his face.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, you've got to admit you've upset a lot of people. At least I can keep my eye on you while you're stuck in here. GRANDFATHER turns away again.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: All right, how about Ringo? I mean ... he's very upset, you know ... and as far as your girlfriend, little Audrey's concerned, she's  finished with men for the rest of her natural, and another thing ...

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: A harmless bit of fun, aah, none of you have any sense of humour left these days.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, it's all right for you but those two girls were scared to death! Honest, Grandad, why? I mean, why do you do these things?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (cutting in) You're left-handed, aren't you, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah ... so what?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Why do you always use your left hand?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, don't be daft, I've got to.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: And I take a left-handed view of life, I've got to. PAUL grins. After a moment of looking at him, PAUL opens the luggage compartment and joins GRANDFATHER on a box.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Shove up! GRANDFATHER produces a penny.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Odds or evens? PAUL sighs.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Odds. GRANDFATHER flips the coin. The guards' van door opens and JOHN, GEORGE and RINGO com them are the girls, RITA and JEAN.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (as he sees PAUL behind the bars) Don't worry, son, we'll get you the best lawyer trading stamps can buy.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, it's a laugh a line with Lennon.  16. nearer 17. 18. (to Ringo) Anyroad up ... It's all your fault.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Me? Why?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Bag-snatcher.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: That's right; convict without trial ... Habeas corpus.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (casually) Every morning. JOHN has been looking around the guards' van.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Gaw, it's depressing in here, isn't it? Funny... (he pats the dog) â€˜cos they usually reckon dogs more than people in England, don't they? You'd expect something a little more palatial. (he shudders) Come on. Let's have a little action. Let's do something, then.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, I've got me gob stopper. (he produces his mouth organ.) Look, a genuine Stradivarius, hand tooled at Dagenham. And to RINGO's beat on a tea chest they are off, PAUL and improvising other sounds, much to the GIRLS' delight. Dur number, GRANDFATHER quietly lets the latch off the chicke chickens begin to wander through the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the number is progressing, the train is getting nea to London.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR PLATFORM TERMINUS, (NIGHT)
dialogues.text: SHOTS of the station full of GIRLS waiting for the BOYS.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR GUARDS VAN
dialogues.text: By the time the number finishes the train pulls up with a  19. 20. that sends them all sprawling, BOYS and GIRLS. NORM enters the guards' van.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Don't move, any of you. They've gone potty out there. The whole place is surging with girls.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Please, can I have one to surge with?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ah, go on, you swine.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: No, you can't. Look, as soon as I tell you, run through this door here and into the big car that's waiting. He points and we see a big car parked across the road. The BOYS prepare to depart, lining up with GRANDFATHER at

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR PLATFORM TERMINUS
dialogues.text: Just as they are ready to go, a line of taxis draws up pa train and now separates them from the big car waiting for

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Oh no! GRANDFATHER pushes past the BOYS, holding his coat closed

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: All right, lads, follow me. And before NORM can stop him, he darts out of the door, P The fans further down the platform see PAUL and charge fo panic NORM and the others follow, JOHN just having time t the girls.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Vive l'amour! NORM drags him away.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR RAILWAY STATION
dialogues.text: The BOYS manage to follow GRANDFATHER by leaping onto a m luggage carrier, GEORGE driving and the other three posin tableau on the back. GRANDFATHER has arrived at a taxi do it open and runs through, opening the other door, thus ma  21. 22. off. hotel 23. is room. the bridge to the car. The BOYS follow and manage to make it to the big car safe towards grandfather's taxi. The FANS have followed the BO streams of GIRLS piling through all the taxis one of whic JOHNSON the city man, opening and shutting the doors to g much to the indignation of the TAXI DRIVERS.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR BIG CAR
dialogues.text: NORM is sitting in front with the driver, FRANK. The four GRANDFATHER are squashed together in the back.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (to the driver) Go like the clappers, son!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (smoothly) That was my entire intention, sir.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STATION
dialogues.text: The car moves off surrounded by the FANS; from a height w converge on the car but it moves forcefully out of the st It moves into the traffic in the main road and the journe begins.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR HOTEL SUITE NIGHT
dialogues.text: There is a reception room and off it lead rooms that are bedrooms, bathroom, etc. JOHN is lying sprawled out on a listening to a transistor radio, demolishing a basket of sitting at an upright piano and GRANDFATHER is mooching a One of the doors opens and GEORGE enters followed by RING BOYS are wearing coats.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: I don't snore.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You do - repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (to John) Do I snore?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (eating a banana) You're a window rattler, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's just your opinion. Do I snore, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (stopping playing) With a trombone hooter like yours it'd be unnatural if you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Don't mock the afflicted, Pauly.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh for Pete's sake, It's only a joke.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Well, it may be a joke, but it's his nose. He can't help having a horrible great nose, it's the only one he's got. And his poor little head's trembling under the weight of it. NORM enters with three piles of fan mail and places them JOHN on a table. RINGO is almost in tears, examining his mirror.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Paul, John, George - get at it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hello the income tax have caught up with us at last. PAUL and GEORGE gather round the low table. RINGO is left

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: None for me, then?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Sorry. John hands RINGO a single envelope.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That'll keep you busy.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: It's your nose, y'see. Fans are funny that way. Take a dislike to things. They'll pick on a nose...

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: You go and pick on your own. SHAKE enters with a stack of mail about three times large the others put together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that yours?

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: For Ringo. He dumps it in Ringo's arms who staggers into an armchair send him up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That must have cost you a fortune in stamps, Ringo.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He comes from a large family.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (dumping the letters) Well. RINGO opens his letter and reads it. It contains a large card.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Eh, what's Boyd's Club? The lads gather round him and PAUL takes the card from hi

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: â€œThe Management of Boyd's takes pleasure in requesting the company of Mr. Richard Starkey that's you, in their recently refinished gaming rooms. Chemin de Fer. Baccarat, Roulette, and Champagne Buffet." Blimey!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (surprised) And they want me?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, it's got round that you're a heavy punter

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (snatching the card Well you're not going.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (taking card from Norm) Quite right, invites to gambling dens full of easy money and fast women, chicken sandwiches and cornets of caviar, disgusting! He pockets the card himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's mine.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Have done, and you lot get your pens out.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: It's homework time for all you college puddings. I want this lot (he indicates the fan letters all answered tonight. The BOYS all protest.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: I'll brook no denial!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It's all right for you, you couldn't get a pen in your foot, you swine.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Come on, Shake, we'll leave â€˜em to their penmanship. He goes followed by SHAKE. There is a pause and JOHN deliberately rises slowly and c coat. He puts it on and walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: While the swine's away the piglets can play. Well, come on, what are we waiting for? With a whoop PAUL, GEORGE and RINGO collect their coats a the door.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: What about all these letters?

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Read â€˜em! They disappear. After a moment GRANDFATHER takes out Ring

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: And a free champagne buffet. He grins to himself. At this moment a WAITER enters with clad in tails and GRANDFATHER eyes them longingly, measur the while alongside the startled waiter. He leaves us wit our minds what he wants, i.e., the waiter's suit

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR DANCING CLUB NIGHT
dialogues.text: The club is the latest in modern decor and full of teenag enjoying themselves. The CAMERA wanders around the club t finally picks out JOHN, PAUL, GEORGE and RINGO all crowded around table. The music is blaring away from a juke box and the dancers. They are recognised and given smiles and nods of encouragement by all the other customers. During this scene we

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR BOYD'S CLUB NIGHT
dialogues.text: The whole atmosphere is of quiet elegance and loud wealth baccarat table the rich, bored customers sit barely movin muscle as they languidly murmur "suivez" and "banco" to t he operates the shoe. The manager of the club is beaming satisfaction as he surveys his customers. One of these cu clad in evening dress and he has his back to us. The rest players (male) are in suits. By each of them is standing with a bored sophisticated face that looks as if it has b on. From the REVERSE of the LAST SHOT we now see the soli dress player is GRANDFATHER. He looks around him and wipe look of enjoyment and elaborately out-bores everyone in the ro

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Alors, M'sieur?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (nonchalant) SouflÃ©e. He turns to the buxom BLONDE, who is dripping over him.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I bet you're a great swimmer. My turn? Bingo!

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: Pas "Bingo," M'sieur... Banco.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (taking) I'll take the little darlings anyway. He takes up the cards and can't understand that they are

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Two and one is three, carry one is four. The buxom BLONDE leans over him.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: Lay them down.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (disturbed by his eyeline) Eh?

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: Lay them down.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: We'd be thrown out.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: Your cards... lay them down... face up. He does so.

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: Huit a la pointe... et sept. (He pushes chips and box to Grandfather.)

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: You had a lovely little pair, y'see.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I dia? CROUPIER taps impatiently on box (shoe).

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: They're yours.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: They are?

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: The cards... you're bank.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR DANCING CLUB
dialogues.text: The BOYS are having a rare old time and the place is real

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR BOYD'S CLUB
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER is playing and a waiter is checking the requi the players.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Bingo!

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: (wearily) M'lord dit "Bingo."

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (to Grandfather)  28. 29. 30. rest. A little light refreshment.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (lordly) A glass of the old chablis to wash down a gesture of giblets wouldn't go amiss. (He resumes his game.) SouflÃ©e, chop chop. The CROUPIER uses the spatula to pick up a card. GRANDFAT and scoops some sandwiches off a passing tray.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR DANCING CLUB
dialogues.text: The BOYS are at their table again laughing and enjoying t when suddenly their faces freeze. From their P.0.V. we see NORM standing glowering down at is SHAKE. Reluctantly the BOYS arise and follow NORM out.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR BOYD'S
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER is looking worried at the call of the card he see that all his chips have gone. He notices the waiter d snacks and champagne to a couple, so quick as a flash, he handkerchief over his arm and writing a bill out on a pie presents it to the couple and collects payment in chips. resumes playing.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR HOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Waiter is sitting on chair in underclothes, reading. He h says "The manager!" and hides in outer clothes closet. NO BOYS enter saying:

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Now get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We were going to do it.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Aye, well, now! (He goes through bedroom.) RINGO goes to hang up coat in closet. He does so, then cr

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Any of you lot put a man in that cupboard?

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: A man? No.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Well somebody did. GEORGE goes to cupboard. We see the WAITER from his P.O. door, returns to group.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He's right, y'know.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: (disinterested) Ah well, there you go. SHAKE enters front door, goes to hang up coat and drags W

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Eh, what's all this?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, him... He's been lurking.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Aye, he looks a right lurker.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: (to WAITER) You're undressed. Where are your clothes?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: The old gentlemen borrowed them to go gambling at Boyd's.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Oh, he's gone to my club, has he?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (turning on Ringo) Yeah, It's all your fault, getting invites to gambling clubs. He's probably in the middle of an orgy by now.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, what are we waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Aye, come on, honest, that grandfather of yours is worse than any of you lot.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR BOYD'S
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER is drinking champagne in locked arms with BLO

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Encore de champagne, Monsieur?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Yes, and I'll have some more champagne as well. He takes another swig of his glass.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (beaming) Lord John McCartney, he's the millionaire Irish Peer, filthy rich of course.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Oh I don't know, looks rather clean to me. The MANAGER comes to grandfather's side.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Play is about to resume, m'lord.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (handing him a chip) Lead me to it, I've a winning itch that only success can pacify. He takes his place at the table. The MANAGER watches for moves away from the table towards the club reception desk

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR RECEPTION DESK BOYD'S CLUB
dialogues.text: JOHN, PAUL, GEORGE, RINGO, NORM and SHAKE are trying to g

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry sir, members and invited guests only.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, GEORGE, RINGO, JOHN
dialogues.text: I've got to get in. It's urgent and important. I've had an invite. Take me to your leader.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Shurrup. The BOYS do and meanwhile the MANAGER has walked into SHO recognises the BOYS and welcomes them with false enthusia start to enter the main room.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: All we want to know is have you got a little old man in there?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Do you mean Lord McCartney?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He's at it again. Look, I'm his grandfather.  I mean...

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: (standing next to Grandfather) Oh, it must be the dolly floor show.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Stay where you are everybody this is a raid and we want him.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Who are these ruffians?... I've never seen them before in my life! ... (etc.) They grab the protesting GRANDFATHER and drag him into th area. He keeps trying to return to BLONDE and table. GEOR each take an end of the velvet cord hanging between the t stanchions. They exchange ends and re-hook it, thus encircling GRANDF entrance desk. They then go to settle up.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (with false charm) Before you go, gentlemen, there's the small matter of the bill. He snaps his fingers and a waiter hands him the bill.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (taking it) I'll settle that. He glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: A hundred and eighty pounds!

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (icily) I beg your pardon, guineas. At that moment a WAITER appears with a tray full of pound

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Your winnings, my lord, one hundred and ninety pounds. The MANAGER tears up the bill and takes the money.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: How about me change?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Cloak room charge. He hands GRANDFATHER his old mackintosh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly) Ah well, easy come, easy go. The others glower at him.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOYS have settled down.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Should I say it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Follow your impulse.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: It'll only get you into trouble.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to RINGO) Aah, shurrup, misery! JOHN slouches forward.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (urgently) O.K. Driver, follow that car!! The driver [Frank] is an urbane young man in a handsome g

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (indicating the traffic) Would you like to be a little more precise, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, that's the wrong line for a start.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sorry? (meaning: "I beg your pardon.")

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, don't pay any attention to him, he was just fulfilling a lifelong ambition.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know, "O.K. Buster, follow that car, there's a sawbuck in it for you if you get real close!"  34. them. 35.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, now I'm with you. [he changes his accent] But, gee, Mister, I've got my license to think of ... we're doing a hundred now ... The car is stopped in traffic behind a bus. JOHN gets out walks to the front. JOHN leans in window delightedly, he wallet.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ever seen one of these before?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ah ... a shamus, eh?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I see you go to the night court.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I've made the scene.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, remember, its Leathery Magee up ahead in that convertible, so cover me in the stake-out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't think that bit's right.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What do you expect from an ad lib ... Raymond Chandler?

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET
dialogues.text: As the big car overtakes a Company Director's Rolls. JOHN window and the boys let out an imaginary hail of bullets Executive in the back. He reacts violently and starts to As he does so, he presses the button of his window, so th only part of it. But what we do is unpleasant. He immedia the button and the window rises. RINGO and PAUL jump out of the car. RINGO takes two drums coat pocket and, using them as banderillas, inserts them into the radiator grill (V.0. "Ole" from the BOYS). PAUL, his coat as a matador's cloak, does a butterfly pass at t has just started up, narrowly missing him, but he keeps i position.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Will you all stop it, you're like a gang of  36. 37. 38. school kids. I knew this was going to happen one day.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (as Ringo and Paul climb in) Well, you shouldn't have had bacon for your breakfast, you cannibal.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
