dialogues.text: Leave him alone, he's got swine fever.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Sit down, the lot of you. At this moment several actors come into the room. They ar in the uniform of officers in Wellington's army. Together they sit down, Beatles and soldiers all mixed up. Now a group of several pretty make-up girls make an entra boys herald their arrival with a chorus of â€œaye aye's" an whistles. JOHN meanwhile has helped himself to a big bear other lads are generally messing about with assorted make

dialogues.speaker: HEAD MAKE UP GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh, this is impossible! We'll never get you all done in time.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR
dialogues.text: Well, you'll just have to do us first... It makes no difference to them whether they're made up or not. (sees John with beard) And who's me, then?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (charmingly) My name's Betty... (pointing to the name on the mirror) Do you want a punch up your frogged tunic? NORM fights his way to JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Now listen, John, behave yourself or I'll murder you and, Shake, take that wig off, it suits you.  girls, SHAKE has a long blond girl's wig on. With the assistance NORM gets the boys seated into the chairs nearest the doo reason RINGO now has a Guardsman's busby wedged down almo eyes and is sitting with it under a hair drier, reading a "Queen" Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (to Ringo) What do you think are you're up to?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Someone put it on me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Excuses, that's all we get and you know you fancy yourself in the Coldstreams. The GIRLS now move in and put make up bibs on the BOYS an powder them off.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You won't interfere with the basic rugged concept of my personality, will you, girl?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Eh, don't take out me lines.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, they give him that "Je ne sais quoi" rakish air. The lads laugh with pleasure. RINGO decides to try a little joke.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (indicating the busby he is still wearing) Short back and sides, please. The other look at him with mock disgust.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Behave...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Foreign devil ...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Control yourself... GRANDFATHER has been watching the powdering process.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: In my considered opinion you're a bunch of sissies.  JOHN grabs a powder puff from his girl.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You know you're only jealous! And dabs the old man liberally with the powder much to GR annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Leave him alone, Lennon, or I'll tell them all the truth about you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You wouldn't!

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: I would though. NORM goes out.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What's he know?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Nothing, he's trying to brainwash me and give me personality doubts ... oh, he's a swine but a clever swine, mind.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Lookit, I thought I was supposed to be getting a change of scenery and so far I've seen a train and a room, a car and a room and a room and a room. Well, that's maybe all right for a bunch of powdered gee-gaws like you lot but I'm feeling decidedly strait-jacketed. This is no life for a free-booting agent of my stamp. I'm a frustrated man and that class of McCartney is a dangerous McCartney.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (admiringly) What a clean old man.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (touchingly) You're too young for a fella of my cosmopolitan tastes, so don't press your luck.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He's sex-obsessed, the older generation are leading this country to galloping ruin. NORM returns leaving the door open, the boys hear the sou coming from the studio.  55. on 56.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: They're nearly ready for you. They're just finishing the band call.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (jumping from his seat) Gear! Come on, girls, let's have a bit of a dance.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN'S GIRL
dialogues.text: I don't think its allowed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well ... it wouldn't be any fun if it was! The BOYS drag the make-up GIRLS out of the room and into The GIRLS are still trying to finish making the BOYS up. As the BOYS and MAKE-UP GIRLS dance past, we see one of t singers combing his long hair straight back. Two STAGE HA wind machine past him and his hair is blown straight forw Beatle cut.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (passing him) Never. During dance, GEORGE takes off wig and places it on dummy identical hair underneath.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR T.V. STUDIO FLOOR
dialogues.text: The work is still going on and the music is up full blast enter and with the GIRLS [and] they start a wild dance, h zulu, blue beat, the lot. LIONEL and DANCERS are doing th one side of the stage ... it becomes a challenge dance be groups. JOHN swings his GIRL onto the motorized CAMERA, W and starts to track through the GROUP. GEORGE is on anoth

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: The whole control room crew are watching the dance on all monitors. him, it The DIRECTOR is about to stop the boys but his GIRL P.A. with a shrug he lets the dance go on. We now cut between the dancers on the monitors and the bo dancing down on the studio floor. When the recorded music grab their instruments and go into a number. So we can watch every aspect of their work and with so ma gives the impression that there are many more boys than j When the number finally ends we are back in the studio o

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR'S VOICE OVER TANNOY
dialogues.text: Thank you gentlemen, you can break now while we push on with the show. The boys acknowledge this with a quaver of guitar chords roll. NORM is on them at once.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: That was great, you've got about an hour but don't leave the theatre. JOHN grabs the arm of a sexy girl dancer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: She's going to show me her stamp collection.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (grabs a showgirl) So's mine.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: John, I'm talking to you. This final run through is important. Understand? Important.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (like a pig) Oink! Oink! They dash off with the two beauties. GRANDFATHER is hovering in the background with SHAKE.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I want me cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Shake.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: I'm adjusting the decibels on the inbalance.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Clever. (he turns) George. But GEORGE is disappearing out of the door. NORM turns to RINGO.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: He comes Look after him.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Do I have to raise me voice?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (choked) Oh, all right. Come here, Grandad. And the two of them walk off, Ringo leading.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: A man, whose act is playing tunes by hitting himself on t swallowing a handful of aspirin tablets. He starts rehear which consists of throwing his head back and slapping his to him, a JUGGLER is practising with four table tennis ba GRANDFATHER passes him and bumps his arm slightly. Only 3 down. There is the sound of coughing off. We

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: THE HEAD-PLAYER being patted on the back. The ball drops mouth and bounces slowly on the studio floor.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR T.V. STUDIO CANTEEN
dialogues.text: The canteen is about half full of actors many of which ar Nazi soldiers, with mock blood bandages and arm bands. Al sprinkling of T.V. people. At a table sits GRANDFATHER an is deeply engrossed in a book and GRANDFATHER has a near tea in front of him. The old man is bored and looks about then looks at Ringo who is innocently occupied, a malicio into GRANDFATHER's eye. He decides to have a go at RINGO staring at him. RINGO gradually becomes aware of the star uncomfortably then tries to continue reading his book.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (disgustedly to no one in particular) Will you ever look at him, sitting there wid his hooter scraping away at that book!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Well ... what's the matter with that?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (taking the book from him) Have you no natural resources of your own? Have they even robbed you of that?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (snatching back his book) You can learn from books.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Can you now? Aah ... sheeps' heads! You learn more by getting out there and living.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Out where?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Any old where ... but not our little Richard ++. oh no! When you're not thumping them pagan skins, you're tormenting your eyes wid that rubbish!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (defiantly) Books are good!

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (countering) Parading's better!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Parading?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (marching up and down the canteen) That's it, parading the streets ... trailing your coat ... bowling along ... living!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Well, I am living, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: You're living, are you? When was the last time you gave a girl a pink-edged daisy? When did you last embarrass a sheila wid your cool appraising stare?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Eh ... you're a bit old for that sort of chat, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: At least I've a backlog of memories, but all you've got is that book!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Aaah ... stop picking on me... you're as bad as the rest of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you are a man after all.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Do you think I haven't noticed ... do you think I wasn't aware of the drift? Oh ... you poor unfortunate scuff, they've driven you into books by their cruel, unnatural treatment, exploiting your good nature.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (not too sure) Oh ... I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (confidingly) And that lot's never happier than when they're jeering at you ... and where would they be without the steady support of your drum beat, I'd like to know.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Yeah ... that's right.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: And what's it all come to in the end?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (defensively) Yeah ... what's in it for me?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: A book!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Yeah ... a bloomin' book! He throws the book down.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: When you could be out there betraying a rich American widow or sipping palm wine in Tahiti before you're too old like me. A fine neat and trim lad the class of you should be helping himself to life's goodies before the sands run out. Being an old age pensioner's a terrible drag on a man and every second you waste is bringing you nearer the Friday queue at the Post Office.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Yeah ... funny really, 'cos I'd never thought of it but being middle-aged and old takes up  most of your time, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (nodding) You're only right.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (nodding back) I'm not wrong. There is a pause, then RINGO rises and crosses to the doo

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Where are you off to?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: I'm going parading before it's too late! RINGO leaves and GRANDFATHER laughs at what he has done, its full meaning and looks worried. 59. INTERIOR CORRIDOR and STAIRWAY RINGO comes along the corridor then down the narrow stair down he comes face to face with GEORGE who is coming up t

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Eh, Ringo, do you know what happened to me?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (passing him) No. I don't. As he goes round the corner RINGO turns on the surprised

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: You want to stop being so scornful, it's twisting your face.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR T.V. THEATRE NEAR STAGE DOORMAN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: JOHN and PAUL are chatting up a couple of girls, when the approaching they break off the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Here he is, the middle-aged boy wonder. RINGO looks at JOHN hard.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Eh. I thought you were looking after the old man.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (with simple dignity) Get knotted! PAUL and JOHN gape at him. For good measure Ringo takes photograph of them before he leaves them flabbergasted an into the street.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We've got only half an hour till the final run-through. He can't walk out on us.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Can't he? He's done it, son! GEORGE runs towards them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Eh, I don't know if you realise it, but ...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We do.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes. Your grandfather's stirred him up.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He hasn't.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes, he's filled his head with notions seemingly.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The old mixer, come on we'll have to put him right. The three of them go into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys look up and down but RINGO has completely disapp

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We'll split up and search for him, he can't be far. They now all start to go off in the same direction, they are three roads they can take but each time they begin to all go the same way.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It's happened at last, we've become a limited company.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll look in here again. PAUL gives him a push to the left and GEORGE to the right straight ahead himself they part and go their separate wa  62.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET
dialogues.text: RINGO is walking along taking photographs with his camera girls recognise him and start to follow him. They quicken and RINGO runs ahead of them. He turns and comes into ano He sees a second-hand clothes shop with a sign saying "We Anything" moment the 63. to tyre and enters the shop just before the pursuing girls come r corner. The girls stand about looking in all directions. RINGO comes out of the shop. He is wearing a long mackint natty cap pulled well down. He is ignored by the girls wh recognise him. Realising this he goes back and ogles one glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Get out of it, short house! CLOSE-UP on Ringo's secret but happy smile as he walks br road.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR TOW PATH CANAL
dialogues.text: RINGO kicks at a brick. He kicks stylishly but misses so misses again, but finally kicks the stone which doesn't b bends down and pulls it out of the ground. It is quite bi quarters of it being below the surface. Having got it he throw it away. As he does so the same POLICEMAN rides pas bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Ain't you got no more bleeding sense than to go round chucking bricks about. Before RINGO has time to answer the man has disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (shouting after him) Southerner! He looks at the canal water moodily; at this moment a lar rolls down the incline and bashes him slap in the back, s on the path, the tyre on top of him. A small boy appears and stands over the prostrate RINGO.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Here, mate, that's my hoop, stop playing with it.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Hoop, this isn't a hoop, it's a lethal weapon. Have you got a licence for it?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Oh don't be so stroppy!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (getting up) Well! A boy of your age bowling "hoop" at people. How old are you anyway?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (aggressively) Nine.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Bet you're only eight and a half.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (countering swiftly) Eight and two thirds.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Well, there you are and watch it with that hoop.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Gerron out of it, you're only jealous â€˜cause you're old.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Shurrup!

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I bet you're (searching for an age) -- sixteen!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Fifteen and two thirds, actually.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: All right, take your hoop and bowl. He moves off and the BOY follows.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Oh you can have it, I'm packing it in -- it depresses me.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Y'what?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: You heard, it gets on my wick.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Well that's lovely talk, that is. And another thing, why aren't you at school?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I'm a deserter.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (smiling in spite of himself) Are you now?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I've blown school out.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Just you?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: No, Ginger, Eddy Fallon and Ding Dong.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Ding Dong? Oh Ding Dong Bell, eh?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right, they was supposed to come with us but they chickened.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Yeah? And they're your mates are they?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (sighing) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Not much cop without 'em, is it?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (defensively) Oh, it's all right.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (disbelievingly) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: What they like? BOY is glad to have something to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically)  Ginger's mad, he says things all the time and Eddy's good at punching and spitting.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: How about Ding Dong?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: He's a big head and he fancies himself with it but you know it's all right â€˜cos he's one of the gang. RINGO nods his head understandingly and they mooch on tog

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Why aren't you at work?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: I'm a deserter, too.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Oh. At this moment a child's voice shouts out "Charley" and f P.O.V. we see three kids. RINGO turns to the BOY and look enquiringly.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (to Ringo) See you. The BOY runs off to join his mates. As he joins them they scuffle together. They are obviously a gang. RINGO is lef

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR CORRIDOR T.V. THEATRE
dialogues.text: GEORGE comes round the corner, looking for RINGO, then gr past a sign saying "Canteen and Production Office Opposit to the exit door, crosses to a modern building across fro theatre. He enters [the] building.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR OFFICE
dialogues.text: It is the reception room that leads to an inner office. B sits a smart young woman typing busily as GEORGE enters. surprised when he sees the girl; she looks up and speaks once.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Oh, there you are!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, I must have made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (tartly) You haven't, you're just late.  66. (She rises and crossing over to him examines him critically.) Oh, yes, he's going to be very pleased with you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is he?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes, you're quite a feather in the cap. (She crosses to the desk and picks up the inter-office phone.) Hello, I've got one ... oh, I think so ... yes, he can talk ... Well ... I think you ought to see him. (she smiles) Of course, right away. She crosses to the inter-office door. On the door is writ MARSHAL ... she opens it.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Well ... come on.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sorry. He follows her quickly in.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR THE INNER OFFICE
dialogues.text: A large room, part production office with models and sets board with ground plans, the other part of the room a mix and Queen's magazine decor. Behind a large desk sits SIMON MARSHAL, a bland but sligh young man of about thirty-five. He is wearing the ultimat current smart set fashion. He is attended by a couple of ADRIAN and TONY and behind him on the wall is a poster of Across the poster is printed, "Way Out, your own T.V. Spe with Susan Campey. Director, Simon Marshal."

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (proudly) Will this do, Simon?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (looking at George) Not bad, dolly, not really bad. (he motions to George) Turn around, chicky baby. GEORGE does so.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Oh yes, a definite poss. He'll look good alongside Susan. (he indicates the girl on the poster) All right, Sunny Jim, this is all going to be quite painless. Don't breathe on me, Adrian. ADRIAN has recognised GEORGE and is trying to stop SIMON.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, I'm terribly sorry but I'm afraid there's been some sort of a misunderstanding.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (sharply) Oh, you can come off it with us. You don't have to do the old adenoidal glottal stop and carry on for our benefit.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, he's a natural. SECRETARY (anxiously) Well, I did tell them not to send us any more real ones.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: They ought to know by now the phonies are much easier to handle. Still he's a good type. He now speaks to GEORGE in the loud voice that the Englis foreigners and village idiots.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: We want you to give us your opinion on some clothes for teenagers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, by all means, I'd be quite prepared for that eventuality.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Well, not your real opinion, naturally. It'll be written out and you'll learn it. (to secretary) Can he read?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course I can.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: I mean lines, ducky, can you handle lines?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll have a bash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Hart, get him whatever it is they drink, a cokearama?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ta.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Well, at least he's polite. Tony Show him the shirts, Adrian. A collection of shirts are produced and GEORGE looks at t is doing this SIMON briefs him.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Now, you'll like these. You really "dig" them. They're "fab" and all the other pimply hyperboles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be seen dead in them. They're dead grotty.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Grotty?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, grotesque.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (to secretary) Make a note of that word and give it to Susan. I think it's rather touching really. Here's this kid trying to give me his utterly valueless opinion when I know for a fact within four weeks he'll be suffering from a violent inferiority complex and loss of status if he isn't wearing one of these nasty things. Of course they're grotty, you wretched nit, that's why they were designed, but that's what you'll want.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But I won't.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: You can be replaced you know, chicky baby.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: And that pose is out too, Sunny Jim. The new thing is to care passionately, and be right wing. Anyway, you won't meet Susan if you don't cooperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who's this Susan when she's at home?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (playing his ace) Only Susan Campey, our resident teenager. You'll have to love her. She's your symbol.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean that posh bird who gets everything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, the lads frequently gather round the T.V. set to watch her for a giggle. Once we even all sat down and wrote these letters saying how gear she was and all that rubbish.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: She's a trend setter. It's her profession!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's a drag. A well-known drag. We turn the sound down on her and say rude things.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Get him out of here!!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (genuinely surprised) Have I said something amiss?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Get him out of here. He's knocking the programme's image!! The underlings hustle GEORGE to the door.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Sorry about the shirts. He is ejected through the door.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Get him out. (he stops in mid-shout) You don't think he's a new phenomenon, do you?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: You mean an early clue to the new direction?

(rummaging in his desk) Where's the calendar? (he finds it) No, he's just a trouble maker. The change isn't due for three weeks. All the same, make a note not to extend Susan's contract. Let's not take any unnecessary chances!

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET PUB ON THE CORNER
dialogues.text: The sign on the pub is Liverpool Arms. RINGO is standing it. He decides to go in and does so.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR T.V. CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is tense. GRANDFATHER is standing miserabl the DIRECTOR, the criminal confronted by the judge. SHAKE flanking him grimly.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry lads, I didn't mean it, honest.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: If he says that again, I'll strike him.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: (unconvincingly) They'll be back, they're good lads, they'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Yes? Well they've got only ten minutes to the final run-through.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I meant no harm. I was only trying to encourage little Ringo to enjoy himself.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (grimly, C.U.) God knows what you've unleashed on the unsuspecting South. It'll be wine, women and song all the way with Ringo once he's got the taste for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP on RINGO. He is eating a bone dry sandwich that the end. He puts it down with disgust. He has a lager gla hand.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAID
dialogues.text: (accusingly) That was fresh this morning. We now see the pub is full of enormous cockney workmen do RINGO is very much alone. He moves away from the bar tow that is standing together, they've an average height of o There is a group at a dart board. Another group is playin skittles and a third group is around a pin-ball table. Near the bar is a shove-halfpenny board with two players. caged parrot nearby.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAID
dialogues.text: (to Ringo) That'll be two and nine... RINGO fumbles some change out of his pocket. A few copper his hand on to the shove-halfpenny board just as the cruc been made. The men glare at him. Embarrassed, he moves aw without looking, places his glass on the skittles table just as a swings the string, which hits Ringo's glass. More embarrassed, R away, unfortunately into the pin-table just as a winning about to be reached. He bumps it very slightly, but enough to c TILT. He then moves to the dart board. By this time most staring at him. With great style he takes the darts. The goes into a cheese sandwich which a man is pointing in de The second we see arrive into a pint of bitter and then w shoot the third dart and hear the sound of the parrot sho angrily, off. The BARMAID has had enough.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAID
dialogues.text: Right ... On your way!

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Y'what?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAID
dialogues.text: You heard, on your way, troublemaker! Now the centre of attention, RINGO backs out of the pub, every eye in the place, the BARMAID and a few players fol the door

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET OUTSIDE PUB
dialogues.text: RINGO comes out and crosses road, watched by the POLICEMA quite suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET
dialogues.text: PAUL comes down the street looking about him for RINGO. I is an old building, the sort of place that is highly favo rehearsals. There is a sign on the door, "TV Rehearsal Ro draws near, a load of actors and extras, etc. are leaving costume, they are the ones who earlier had been going to rehearsal. When PAUL gets near the entrance he decides to  72. 73.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR HALL
dialogues.text: PAUL enters and wanders about. He reaches a door, pushes looks in. He sees a GIRL clad in period costume. She is m the room and obviously acting. PAUL watches her for a mom decides to go in.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR REHEARSAL ROOM
dialogues.text: PAUL goes into the room. The GIRL is in mid-flight. She i and lovely and completely engrossed in what she is doing. absolutely empty except for PAUL and herself. She is acti manner of an eighteenth-century coquette, or, to be preci English actresses use when they think they are being true costume period ... her youth however makes it all very ch

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: If I believed you, sir, I might do those things and walk those ways only to find myself on Problem's Path. But I cannot believe you, and all those urgings serve only as a proof that you will lie and lie again to gain your purpose with me. She dances lightly away from an imaginary lover and as sh sees PAUL who is as engrossed in the scene as she was.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (surprised) oh!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) Well ... go â€˜head, do the next bit.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Go away! You've spoilt it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry I spoke. He makes no attempt to go. He simply continues to look st girl; then he smiles at her. She is undecided what to do

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you supposed to be here?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I've got you worried, haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm warning you, they'll be back in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: D'you know something, "They" don't worry me at all. Anyroad, I only fancy listening to you  .Â».. that's all but if it worries you ... well ...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You're from Liverpool, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (ironically) How'd you guess?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (seriously) Oh, it's the way you talk.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (innocently) Is it ... is it, really?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) Are you pulling my leg?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (looking her straight in the eye) Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (unsure) I see. (airily) Do you like the play?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah ... I mean, sure, well, I took it at school but I only ever heard boys and masters saying those lines, like, sounds different on a girl. (smiles to himself) Yeah, it's gear on a girl.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Gear?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aye, the big hammer, smashing!

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don't mench ... well, why don't you give us a few more lines, like? GIRL pouts.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You don't half slam the door in people's faces,  do you? I mean, what about when you're playing the part, like, hundreds of people'll see you and...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (cutting in) I'm not ...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, you're the understudy, sort of thing?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: No. (aggressively) I'm a walk-on in a fancy dress scene. I just felt like doing those lines.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. You are an actress though, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aye, I knew you were.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, the way you were spouting, like .... (he imitates her) "I don't believe you, sir..." and all that. Yeah, it was gear.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (dryly) The big hammer?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (smiling) Oh aye, a sledge.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: But the way you did it then sounded so phony.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No ... I wouldn't say that ... just like an actress ... you know. He moves and stands about like an actress.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: But that's not like a real person at all.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aye well, actresses aren't like real people, are they?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: They ought to be.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know, anyroad up, they never are, are they?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (teasingly) What are you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm in a group ... well ... there are four of us, we play and sing.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I bet you don't sound like real people.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We do, you know. We sound like us having a ball. It's fab.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Is it really fab or are you just saying that to convince yourself?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What of? Look, I wouldn't do it unless I was. I'm dead lucky 'cos I get paid for doing something I love doing. He laughs and with a gesture takes in the whole studio

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: -+. all this and a jam butty too!!

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I only enjoy acting for myself. I hate it when other people are let in.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why? I mean, which are you, scared or selfish?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Why selfish?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, you've got to have people to taste your treacle toffee. She looks at him in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, hang on, I've not gone daft. You see, when  I was little me mother let me make some treacle toffee one time in our back scullery. When I'd done she said to me, "Go and give some to the other kids." So, I said I would but I thought to meself, "She must think I'm soft." Anyroad, I was eating away there but I wanted somebody else to know how good it was so in the end I wound up giving it all away ... but I didn't mind, mind, â€˜cos I'd made the stuff in the first place. Well ... that's why you need other people... an audience ... to taste your treacle toffee, like. Eh ... does that sound as thickheaded to you as it does to me?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Not really but I'm probably not a toffee maker. How would you do those lines of mine?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, look at it this way, I mean, when you come right down to it, that girl, she's a bit of a scrubber, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Is she?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Of course ... Look, if she was a Liverpool scrubber ... (Paul starts acting a Liverpool girl, he minces about then turns, extending his leg) Eh, fella, you want to try pulling the other one, it's got a full set of bells hanging off it... Y'what? ... I know your sort, two cokes and a packet of cheese and onion crisps and suddenly it's love and we're stopping in an empty shop doorway. You're just after me body and y'can't have it ... so there!!

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (shattered) And you honestly think that's what she meant?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, definitely, it sticks out a mile, she's trying to get him to marry her but he doesn't want ... well ... I don't reckon any fella's ever wanted to get married. But girls are like that, clever and cunning. You've got to laugh. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Well, it's nice to know you think we're clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) And cunning.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: And what do you do about it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Me? Oh, I don't have the time, I'm always running about with the lads ... no, we don't have the time.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Pity.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (not noticing the invitation) Aye, it is but as long as you get by, it's all right, you know ... bash on, happy valley's when they let you stop. Anyroad, I'd better get back.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (going) See you.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Of course. PAUL stands at the doorway, shrugs then goes out.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET
dialogues.text: In the street, workmen are collecting shovels, drinking t all the things people do around building sites. RINGO moo In the road is a hole with a diameter of about 3 feet, an feet deep. RINGO looks down and a man is busily working a of the hole. He glares at RINGO. After a moment RINGO tur now see a very elegant young lady coming towards RINGO. S daintily avoiding a series of puddles. RINGO has an idea and does Raleigh with his large Mac spreading it over one of the p girl walks across it smiling graciously. RINGO proceeds w to the next puddle and to the next backing gradually towa At last he spreads the coat, without noticing what he is the hole. The girl steps onto the coat and disappears sha looks down the hole where the girl is held in the workman workman rises out of the manhole until he is waist height point an elegantly dressed gentleman appears (the girl's looks at his wife in the workman's arms and hits the work backs away through the puddles, and is nicked by the POLI [Scenes 75 and 76 deleted in revision. ]  77.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR T.V. THEATRE NEAR STAGE DOOR
dialogues.text: The DIRECTOR is pacing up and down the corridor. NORM is up and down, SHAKE is leaning against the wall quite unco gives SHAKE a push.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Worry, will you! SHAKE adjusts his features to a worrying expression.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Well, that's it, two minutes to the final run-through... they're bound to miss it...

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: I'll murder that Lennon.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: But I suppose we can survive a missed run-through as long...

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: ... as they head up for the show. Oh yes, well I mean it'ud be a pity to miss the show, wouldn't it like.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Shurrup, cheerful. The horrible prospect hits the DIRECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: You don't think...

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (reassuring him) They'll be here.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Oh now, they can't do that to me. (turning on Norm) It's all your fault. (overriding Norm) Oh yes it is and if they don't turn up I wouldn't be in your shoes for all the...

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: (helping out) ... tea in China. Oh you're right, neither would I. He steps away from NORM and stands near the DIRECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Traitor! SHAKE nods his agreement to this assessment of his chara

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Of course. At this moment JOHN, GEORGE and PAUL enter from the stage are completely unconcerned and walk past the DIRECTOR, SH

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (as he passes by) Hi Norm!

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) Hi, our lot! The BOYS walk on when after a moment NORM snaps to.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Our lot!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (mildly) Did you want something.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (beaming with delight) I could eat the lot of you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You'd look gear with an apple in your gob.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (accusingly) Do you realise you could have missed the final run-through?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SHAKE
dialogues.text: Eh, there's only three of them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aye, we were looking for Ringo. But we realised he must have come back.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Do you realise we are on the air, live, in front of an audience, in forty-five minutes and you're one short.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Control yourself or you'll spurt. He's bound to be somewhere.  78. who hop 79.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Aye, let's try the dressing room. Everyone starts along the passage. NORM and PAUL last.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Eh, where's my grandfather?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Don't worry about him. He can look after himself.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aye, I suppose so. They run after the others.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Here they are, personally signed and handwritten by your own sweet boys. The chance of a lifetime. Be the envy of your less fortunate sisters! The CAMERA PULLS back and we see GRANDFATHER is surrounde have broken from the queue and are doing a brisk trade wi man. He has a large sign on which is written: "Get your g autographed Beatles photographs." On the edge of the crow POLICEMEN are trying to force the girls back into the que they wade through the girls and confront GRANDFATHER. The old man quizzically; he stares back coldly. They indicate it and quick but GRANDFATHER defiantly glares back at the sigh, they grab an arm each and escort the old man off.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: It is the reception desk and behind it is the DESK SERGEA moment RINGO is dragged in by the POLICEMAN we saw him wi

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Look, I'm Ringo Starr... I've got a show to do in a few minutes you've got to let me go... I'm Ringo...

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Sure, they all say that these days ... Anyway ++. I don't care who you are... you can save that for the stipendary. Here you are, Sarge.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: What is he?

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: (reeling off the list)  I've got a little list here. Wandering abroad. Malicious intent. Acting in a suspicious manner. Conduct liable to cause a breach of the peace. You name it, he's done it.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Oh, a little savage, is he?

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: A proper Aborigine.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (on his dignity) I demand to see me solicitor.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Oh, well if you're going to get technical -- At that moment there is a loud series of noises off camer shouting and dull crashes of wood.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Hello, it's going to be one of those nights, is it? (to policeman) sit Charley Peace down over there. The POLICEMAN takes RINGO to a bench and sits him down as and the two POLICEMEN who were with him enter. The sign i and is being lugged after them.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Well, you got me here so do your worst but I'll take one of you with me. (kicks the nearest policeman) Oh, I know your game, get me in the tiled room and out come the rubber hoses but I'll defy you still.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Is there a fire, then? GRANDFATHER leans across the desk and hisses at the SERGE

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: You ugly, great brute you, you have sadism stamped all over your bloated British kisser.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I'll go on a hunger strike. I know your caper. The kidney punch and the rabbit-clout. The  third degree and the size twelve boot ankle-tap.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: What's he on about?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (squaring up) I'm soldier of the Republic, you'll need the mahogany truncheon for this boyo. A nation once again.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (to policemen) Get Lloyd George over there with that mechanic in the cloth cap while I sort this lot out. The POLICEMEN hurtle GRANDFATHER firmly but gently over t which RINGO is sitting and then return to the desk for a conference with the SERGEANT. Meanwhile in full conspirat GRANDFATHER talks to RINGO out of the side of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Ringo, me old scout, they grabbed yer leg for the iron too, did they?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Well I'm not exactly a voluntary patient.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Shush! Have they roughed you up yet?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (whispering) Keep your voice down, this lot'll paste you, just for the exercise. Oh they're a desperate crew of drippings and they've fists like matured hams for pounding defenceless lads like you.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (disturbed) Have they?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: That sergeant's a body-blow veteran if ever I measured one. One of us has got to escape. I'll get the boys. Hold on son, I'll be back for you.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (horrified) Me !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if they get you on the floor watch out for your brisket.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (hopefully) Oh, they seem all right to me.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: That's what they want you to think. All coppers are villains.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (calling) Would you two like a cup of tea?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: You see, sly villains.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (miserable) No thanks, Mr. Sergeant, sir. We now have a CLOSE SHOT of POLICEMEN around the sergeant

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: So you just brought the old chap out of the crowd for his own good.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he insisted on us bringing him to the station.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Well, he can't stop here. Shot of GRANDFATHER watching POLICEMEN intently and mutte he does.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Lip reading.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: What are they saying?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Nothing good. The POLICEMEN make a move towards GRANDFATHER and RINGO.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Well son, it's now or never. He jumps to his feet and scurries towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you paid assassins. Johnny McCartney'll give you a run for your threepence ha'penny. He dashes out of the door followed by the POLICEMAN who h of photos.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Now, what's he up to?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: He's allergic to Bobbies, especially English Bobbies. The POLICEMAN with the photos returns.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: (Irish accent) Your man disappeared like a leveret over a hill.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Turncoat! The POLICEMEN turn on RINGO and walk towards him.

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: Mother!

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER is running at top speed down the street. He i heavily and runs as if pursued by the hounds of hell. The however is entirely empty and no one is even in sight. As the top of the street he pauses and turning, looks around his P.O.V. we see just how empty the street is and heaving a relief GRANDFATHER cackles to himself. His triumph is short live precise moment down the street comes a parade of police v Black Maria, an escorting police motor bike patrol and an squad car. The procession draws up and the street is full getting out of the Black Maria and squad car and off moto CLOSE-UP GRANDFATHER's horrified face.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Be God, they've called up reinforcements, the dragnet's out! He dashes off wildly in the general direction of the thea been completely unnoticed by the policemen who are lining last minute inspection by the inspector in charge. The inspec commander-in-chief of a spear-head attack force. They smartly march off in the direction taken by GRANDFAT 81. INTERIOR T.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (watching the clock) Only half an hour and you're on!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Can I say something? The director clutches at any straw.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (hopefully) Yes, anything.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (earnestly) It's highly unlikely we'll be on... I mean the law of averages are against you and it seems that, etc., etc.... But his speech is drowned by the pitiful moans of the DIR

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR T.V. THEATRE STAGE DOOR
dialogues.text: The four little boys from the canal are being driven away security guard.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: (going back into theatre) I'll have the hides off of you lot. The kids retreat as GRANDFATHER pants into shot, ignoring enters the stage door but in a second he is out again, gr by the collar by the security guard.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: You ought to be ashamed of yourself. Go home!

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: I must see Pauly.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Go home then and see him on the telly. The GUARD re-enters the stage door. GRANDFATHER looks around him and sees the four kids. He h and after a whispered conference we hear his offer.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Can you fix him for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Sixpence.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Each? GRANDFATHER is about to argue.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Oh, all right.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: And in advance.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Mercenary! But he hands over the money. The kids rush in the stage d a moment the furious GUARD chases them out and down the a GRANDFATHER, chuckling, nips in the door.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR T.V. CONTROL ROOM ON STAGE
dialogues.text: GRANDFATHER is being chased by several studio attendants; dodging behind equipment. He finally gets on a sound boom trolley as a weapon to keep his pursuers at bay.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR T.V. CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: The DIRECTOR, BOYS, and NORM and SHAKE see GRANDFATHER on monitors. They dash out of the room and on to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (shouting) It's all right, leave him alone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Grandad, where's Ringo?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: The police have the poor unfortunate lad in the Bridewell.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: The police station.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: He'll be pulp by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: station coppers 86. 87. What are we waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Come here. PAUL, JOHN and GEORGE rush off.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: We've only got twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STREET OUTSIDE POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: PAUL, JOHN and GEORGE come running down the street in sin their knees high in the air, they skid to a halt at the p and without pausing they dash inside. After a moment they only this time RINGO is behind them. They dash off down t They are followed at once by ten POLICEMEN also in single are also pounding along knees high in the air. The BOYS a disappear around the corner. At once, they reappear from direction, then run down the street still followed by the When they reach the police station another group of polic way so they are forced to run up the stairs and inside.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: The DESK SERGEANT is standing behind his desk looking ver At this moment the boys run in and stand panting in front Before the SERGEANT can start speaking the pursuing POLIC They, too, are out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: What is all this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (heaving and panting) Hold on until we get our breath. The BOYS and POLICEMEN pant on until JOHN seems to have r

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: All right now?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sure. (to boys) Ready? The BOYS nod and without further ado they turn and run th surprised rank of POLICEMEN and out into the street.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHASE CARRIES ON.
dialogues.text: Shots of BOYS being pursued (still in single file) by po including the sergeant with one shot where the BOYS are chasing the Finally, as they approach the theatre, they are seen by t who swarm around the police, over running them. The boys other and are about to make off when from their P.O.V. we INSPECTOR and POLICEMEN blocking it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ah well, it was worth a try.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (calling to Sergeant) What do you think you're up to?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Arrest those boys, sir.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: That's all we need to start a real riot! (to Boys) Come on lads, they're waiting for you. Het INTERIOR THEATRE BACKSTAGE The Inspector now hustles the BOYS through the crowds and the main entrance of the theatre where SHAKE and NORM are

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: looks suspiciously at RINGO who is still wearing his cap. it off and NORM delightedly hugs him. The BOYS dash throu entrance and on stage. The DIRECTOR sees them and bursts with relief. NORM hustles the lads into the wings to be c their show costumes. All around them last-minute preparat going on.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Boys, you don't know what this means to me. If you hadn't come back it would have been the epilogue or the news in Welsh for life.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: Aren't you supposed to be in that box? The DIRECTOR gives NORM a final glare and dashes off.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And another thing, where's that old mixer?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: Here, Pauly. And sitting on a box sadly chastened sits GRANDFATHER.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, I got a few things to say to you, two-faced John McCartney.  old 88. of

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Aw, leave him alone Paul, he's back, isn't he? And it's not his fault he's old.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (hotly) What's old got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You needn't bother.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Y'what?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Practising to be thick-headed, you're there already.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Look he's a mixer and a trouble maker!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That's right, but he's only asking us to pay attention to him, aren't you? From JOHN's P.O.V. we see GRANDFATHER. He looks what he i man.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You see. (to Grandad) You know your trouble -- you should have gone West to America. You'd have wound up a Senior Citizen of Boston. As it is you took the wrong turning and what happened, you're a lonely old man from Liverpool.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (fighting back) But I'm clean. The BOYS giggle and slap him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR TV THEATRE AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: We see the audience of girls streaming in and settling do places for the show. There is the usual business of getti ready and we see SHOTS of the girls' faces, then JOHN, PA GEORGE looking at them. At last on cue from the floor man start their act to the audience's screams. During the num constantly CUT away to the audience with various SHOTS of girls. In the middle of these shots we see NORM standing  and spite medley of finish 89. the audience his face glowing with satisfaction. We follo from NORM'S P.O.V. we see GRANDFATHER handcuffed to SHAKE of this, the old man is enjoying himself. The BOYS now pe of numbers, i.e., a little of all the songs we have heard story. This gives the impression of a full set and we fin their bows. While they are doing so they look again in th direction of SHAKE and GRANDFATHER and from their P.O.V., is beating time to the music but from his wrist dangles a handcuffs. GRANDFATHER has gone again. As the BOYS are re GRANDFATHER's disappearance once again, the trap door on opens and GRANDFATHER appears in the centre of the group their act and take their final bows.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR STUDIO CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: NORM is waiting for the boys. With him are two studio att carrying the boys' luggage. As the BOYS excitedly appear them.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: I've got the stuff. Come here.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aren't we ...

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: No, we're not! He hurries them along.

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: The office was on the phone, they think it'd be better if we pushed straight to Wolverhampton.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Tonight? We can't make it ...

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: You've got a midnight matinee.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Now, look here, Norm...

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: No, you look here, John. I've only one thing to say to you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: You're a swine. So hurry up ... we're  travelling! NORM turns down a side exit where the door is open to the is an eight-passenger helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR STAGE DOOR T.V. THEATRE
dialogues.text: The BOYS and NORM come out of the building and start to r the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (looking behind him) Where's my grandfather?

dialogues.speaker: NORM
dialogues.text: (arriving at helicopter door) Don't start. Look. The boys look in the passenger bay and there is GRANDFATH still handcuffed to SHAKE but clutching his pile of photo

dialogues.speaker: GRANDFATHER
dialogues.text: (beckoning them in with his free hand which holds the photos) Come on, you're hanging up the parade. The boys shout â€œGet rid of those things, etc."

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR FIELD
dialogues.text: The final shot is of the helicopter rising up (SHOT FROM disappears, a shower of photos come from its window. We cut to a CLOSE-UP of one signed photo as it hits the g SUPER the closing credits over it. Screenplay by Alun Owen
